The landmarks such as the Eiffel Tower, the Statue of Liberty, the Taj Mahal, and the Great Wall of China have been depicted in various forms of art, literature, and films. For instance, the Eiffel Tower has been celebrated in a number of paintings, photographs, and films, ranging from the famous French New Wave movie "Breathless" to Gustave Eiffel's original sketches. Similarly, the Statue of Liberty has been featured in numerous movies such as "The Day After Tomorrow" and "Ghostbusters II," and also portrayed in paintings and literature.

The Taj Mahal has been the subject of countless paintings and photographs, including masterpieces by artists such as William Hodges and Edwin Lord Weeks. The beauty of the Taj Mahal has been immortalized in numerous poems and songs, evoking the emotions of love, passion, and tragedy. Meanwhile, the Great Wall of China has been immortalized in paintings, books, and poetry that describe its strategic importance and the hard work of the laborers who built it. The Great Wall has also been the backdrop of several movies such as Disney’s “Mulan”.

The cultural significance of these landmarks has been greatly influenced by how they are depicted in art, literature, and films. Artistic portrayals have played an important role in popularizing these landmarks across different cultures, which has led to increased tourism and appreciation of these iconic structures. Additionally, the depiction of landmarks in film and literature has added to their global recognition, and they have become a symbol of national pride, representing the identity and heritage of the respective countries.

Overall, the depiction of these landmarks in art, literature, and films has helped to shape their cultural significance, and they have become a testament to human creativity and ingenuity, providing a window into the past while inspiring the present and future generations.
